tasks: Review Tesler's Law (https://lawsofux.com/teslers-law/) and explain its impact on UX design. Write a 2-page report detailing how this law can be applied to improve your current designs.
Practice Hick’s Law (https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law/) by creating 5 wireframes for a navigation menu, ensuring that the time it takes to complete each task is optimized for the user's needs.
Create an Aesthetic-Usability Effect (https://lawsofux.com/aesthetic-usability-effect/) analysis of your current portfolio. Identify areas where the design could be improved to increase usability.
Conduct a user research exercise using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework (https://lawsofux.com/jobs-to-be-done/) on a current project. Document 5 pain points and potential solutions.

Develop a 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design (https://www.nngroup.com/articles/ten-usability-heuristics/) checklist to apply to your future designs. Focus on the heuristics that align with your weak area in UX Fundamentals.
Create a simple usability test plan using the 8-point grid system (https://lawsofux.com/8-point-grid-system/) and apply it to a current design element.
Develop a Product Thinking & Strategy framework for your current project. Identify key product goals, user needs, and potential solutions.
Create a UX Fundamentals case study (using the Laws of UX) on how to improve the navigation menu of a recent design. Focus on applying principles from Tesler's Law and Hick’s Law.
Design an error state for a current project using the 8-point grid system. Ensure that the error message is clear, concise, and provides a solution.

Create a comprehensive UX Fundamentals portfolio showcasing your understanding of key principles such as Tesler's Law, Hick’s Law, and Aesthetic-Usability Effect. Include examples from previous projects.
Develop a Product Thinking & Strategy plan for a hypothetical product. Focus on how to apply the framework to improve user experience and meet business goals.
Conduct an in-depth analysis of your current design process using the 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design checklist. Identify areas where you can improve your UX Fundamentals skills.

resources.readup: As a Strategic Lead UX designer, you have the unique opportunity to drive user-centered design decisions across multiple products and teams. By leveraging your strengths in UI Craft & Visual Design, User Research & Validation, and Collaboration & Communication, you can create seamless and intuitive experiences that delight users and drive business success.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick’s Law and its Impact on UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to inform design decisions about response time, navigation, and feedback.
practice_points: Conduct a usability test with 5 participants to measure the impact of response time on user experience. Analyze the results using Hick’s Law as a framework for interpretation
Create a wireframe prototype of a search bar with varying response times to demonstrate how Hick's Law affects user behavior

topics.name: Developing a Comprehensive Style Guide Using Tesler’s Law
topics.summary: Applying Tesler’s Law to create a style guide that minimizes cognitive load and maximizes visual appeal.
practice_points: Create 3 style guides for different UI components (e.g., buttons, forms) using Tesler’s Law as the guiding principle. Document design decisions and rationale
Conduct an A/B testing experiment to compare two versions of a UI component with varying levels of visual complexity

topics.name: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Von Restorff Effect in UX Design
topics.summary: Applying the Von Restorff Effect to create attention-grabbing and memorable UI elements.
practice_points: Design 5 different UI elements (e.g., icons, labels) using the Von Restorff Effect to increase cognitive salience. Test with 10 participants and document results
Create a visual hierarchy of a webpage using the Von Restorff Effect as a guiding principle
